heading: house to hold icann hearing
subheading: a virginia republican has asked the internet corporation for assigned names and numbers to attend a house hearing and defend its plans to ding domain name holders. by declan mccullagh.
author: declan mccullagh
text: a congressional committee will hold a hearing to investigate icann, the controversial organization created to manage internet domain names. the house commerce committee, chaired by representative tom bliley (r-virginia), has asked the internet corporation for assigned names and numbers (icann) to send a representative to the 22 july hearing, the group said wednesday.the panel's decision comes after tax and government watchdog groups sent letters last month clamoring for action, arguing congress should investigate the fees that icann is planning to charge anyone with a domain name.a committee source told wired news at the time that a hearing was likely to ensure "there's no disruption in the process of running the internet."ralph nader also wrote a letter asking interim icann chairman esther dyson to answer some questions about what powers the group would have, the source of its authority, and how much control it will have over internet addresses.in a letter to the house commerce committee, icann last week defended itself against charges of secrecy, unaccountability, and unreasonable taxation."icann has no power or authority to impose anything on anyone, and it has not attempted to do so," wrote esther dyson.
